Subject: Junit 3.4 + RedHat Linux 7.0 == 2 test failures?

From: "Mike Greiner" <mikegreiner@...>

Hello All,

I just unzipped junit 3.4 on my RedHat 7.0 linux box (i386) and tried to run the sample tests to verify the install. When run with Sun's JDK 1.3 I see the following:

:-) >java junit.textui.TestRunner junit.samples.AllTests
..........................................................................F.F...
Time: 16.399
 
FAILURES!!!
Test Results:
Run: 78 Failures: 2 Errors: 0
There were 2 failures:
1) testError(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest) "expected:<-1> but was:<0>"
2) testFailure(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest) "expected:<-1> but was:<0>"        


When run with the Blackdown 1.2.2 JDK it still fails, but with an return value of 255 rather than 0:

:-) >java junit.textui.TestRunner junit.samples.AllTests
..........................................................................F..F..
Time: 1.928
 
FAILURES!!!
Test Results:
Run: 78 Failures: 2 Errors: 0
There were 2 failures:
1) testFailure(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest) "expected:<-1> but was:<255>"
2) testError(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest) "expected:<-1> but was:<255>"     


I changed my path each time to pick up the desired JDK. I'm on day 2 of my junit experimentation (yesterday had good success with version 2.1 but I wanted to check out the new stuff) so it's quite possible I'm doing something wrong.

Version 3.4 seems to be working fine for the few tests I've written myself, but I'd like the secure feeling of seeing junit's own self-tests pass.

Suggestions?

Thanks much, Mike


P.S. Yes, for whatever reason, Blackdown's JDK 1.2.2 is much faster running these tests than Sun's JDK 1.3.
subject: Junit 3.4 + RedHat Linux 7.0 == 2 test failures?
